title: Exercise Northstar: After Action
description: The exercise is over. Command wants a data-driven report analysing unit readiness, decision speed, and logistics efficiency. Your analysis will shape how the SAF trains for the next 5 years.
storyContext: Exercise Northstar is over. Vehicles are rolling back to camp and everyone is exhausted, but the work is not done. The Chief of Army wants a data-driven report on unit readiness, decision speed, and logistics efficiency within two weeks. The findings will shape how the SAF trains for the next five years. Your team has mountains of GPS tracks, supply logs, radio transcripts, and decision timestamps. Time to turn raw data into answers that matter.

software-engineer.title: Build the Review Tool
software-engineer.instruction: The generals want an interactive tool that lets them replay the entire exercise, scrolling through a timeline like a video player to see how decisions played out with data on screen. How do you build it?
software-engineer.hint: Think about the trade-off between giving commanders something rich and interactive versus something simpler that is ready sooner and easy to share.

options.label: Build a full replay tool with the actual map, unit movements, and decision markers. Takes 2 weeks but commanders can rewatch the entire exercise with data annotations.
Generate a report with charts, key-moment screenshots, and auto-generated insights. Done in 3 days and easy to share as a document. No interactive replay though.
Use AI to automatically find the 20 most critical moments and generate a short analysis for each. Novel approach but the AI might miss events that don't look dramatic in the data.
Build a shared tool where unit commanders can mark up the timeline with their own observations. Richer insights from multiple people but takes time to collect everyone's input.

data-scientist.title: Calculate Unit Readiness Scores
data-scientist.instruction: The generals want a single readiness score for each unit. You have GPS tracks, supply requests, radio logs, and decision timestamps to work with. Put the analysis steps in the right order to produce credible results.
data-scientist.hint: Bad data makes bad scores. Agree on the definition before you calculate anything. Then verify your results against what actually happened.

items.label: Clean the raw data by removing sensor errors and duplicate entries
Agree with the exercise planners on what readiness actually means and how to measure it
Calculate a readiness score for each unit using the agreed definition
Compare the scores against what human observers reported to catch any mistakes
Show the results to command with charts and an honest note on how confident you are in the numbers

cloud-engineer.title: Work Out How Much Storage You Need
cloud-engineer.instruction: The exercise ran for 14 days and all the data needs to be saved for future training analysis. The graph shows how many terabytes were produced each day over the last 4 days. Estimate the total storage needed for all 14 days, then add 30% on top for the file organisation system.
cloud-engineer.hint: Estimate the total data for 14 days first, then add 30% on top for the overhead.
